# Building JS Apps with API Data
---

Hello, [Wrold](https://medium.com/@the_taqquikarim/console-log-hello-wrold-3e3abeb44396#.vk701xxec)! Welcome to Javascript APIs.

### Objective
---
Our main today is to learn how we can leverage 3rd party APIs to enrich our webpages with dynamic data.

We will cover **public APIs** only, since those don't require anything more than some js code to configure. This means we will **not** talk about the twitter or facebook APIs which require a user authentication component to work correctly.

##### What we will talk about
APIs. RESTful verbs. GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. Retrieving data. Displaying data. Promises. Asynchronous operations. Templating.

##### What we will NOT talk about
Routing. This is not an SPA class though typically pulling API data and displaying them via frontend routes are very closely related. If we have time towards the end we will consider going over this.

### Game Plan
---

#### [Warm-up: Simple GET requests](#warm-up)
The assumption is you've probably worked with API data before. Even if you have not, with jQuery, it's literally just 4 or 5 lines of code to get started.

#### [Wrangling Asynchronousness: Dealing with multiple requests](#wrangling-asynchronousness)
How do we force asynchronous requests to execute in order?

#### [Exploring RESTful APIs: What is REST?](#exploring-restful-apis)
We have a good handle on GET requests, but what about all the other types? Specifically POST, PUT, DELETE?

#### [Using Promises: Better handling asynchronous requests](#using-promises)
What are promises and how can we use them to make it easier for us to draw data together from multiple sources?

# Wrangling Asynchronousness: Dealing with multiple requests
---

Next, we will talk about the asynch problem with handling AJAX requests. What happens when we try to combine a few AJAX calls at once?

## Project Work
---

#### Project 2 (we do)
Let's build a weather app. It will display the weather data from three cities in order. 

For example, if my choices were:

* NYC
* Palo Alto
* Moscow

Then, I should see weather data for NYC before Palo Alto before Moscow.

We will use the [OpenWeatherMap](http://openweathermap.org/) API for this project.

#### Follow up (you do)
Now, let's make things interesting. **Combine** our work from the Giphy API with out work with this WeatherMap API. 

**How it should work**

Modify our app so that the weather for each city is accompanied by a gif from the Giphy API that reflects the current weather condition. It should load in the same order as defined above, though. 

**Example output**

For example, if it is rainy in NYC tomorrow and cloudy on Tuesday, I expect Monday's image to be:

![alt text](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT5LMStuLNrOPa6hry/giphy.gif)

and Tuesday's image to be:

![alt text](https://media.giphy.com/media/xT5LMWxitRdSMvtS4E/giphy.gif)

**Load sequence (challenge)**

Build the app so that the weather content for say New York **only** shows up after **both** the weather data **AND** the Giphy data has loaded.

exploring-restful-apis.content:
# Exploring RESTful APIs: What is REST? 
---
As it turns out, GET is only one of a few possible ways to interact with API data.

## RESTful APIs
---
REST stands for **Representational State Transfer**. RESTful APIs define a protocol for requesting data from a server and/or requesting updates to the datastore of a server. 

The REST protocol defines several verbs that can be used to request data/changes.

#### GET
This is the one we know very well. GET requests are essentially DB reads, meaning we use GET requests to grab information as it is stored in the server.

#### POST
POST requests send data to a specific API endpoint. The expectation is the API endpoint handler determines what to do with the data and responds with an identifier that describes the changes it made.

Typically, we use POST requests to create new rows of data in a DB.

For example, doing something like

`POST /v1/article/create`

would tell the server handling this request to create a new article row in the DB and return a unique identifier (ie: `id = 12483`) for the newly created row to the client.

#### PUT
The PUT request typically will push some form of data (or "resource") directly to a specified endpoint. If no resource exists at that endpoint, it will create it. If a resource does exist at that endpoint, it will replace it.

Going back to our previous example, if we wanted to update our article, we could do something like:

`PUT /v1/article/12483`

And at this point, whatever data we pass along with our request will be updated into the db row that corresponds to that particular article.

**Important note**

When do you PUT and when do you POST? Theoretically, you can POST an update to a resource and you can PUT a new resource. 

Typically, you would PUT when you know the exact location (ie: `id = 12483`) of the resource. You should POST when you do **not** know what the location of the resource is and would rather have the server decide.

#### DELETE
Deletes a resource. Make sure you know it's location though.

## Project Work
---
#### Project 3 (we do)
Let's create a blog website using the [Trello API](https://developers.trello.com/).

This is a two part project. Part 1 -- this part -- will be concerned with creating a UI for bloggers to add content.

Part 2 -- the follow up -- will be the creation of a "front-end" so that users on the internet can consume the blogged content. 

##### Premise
We wish to create a blogging app for users who want super basic blogs. We will use Trello as our "backend" because it is cheap and does not require a server (this is good for us to prototype out this MVP). 

We want to abstract away everything that has to do with Trello, the user should not have to leave our app in order to do anything on Trello itself.

##### Requirements
1. User has the ability to create a new public board. This board will be the "db" for the subsequent articles.
2. User has the ability to add an article with a "tag" (this basically means creating a card under a specific list)
3. User has the ability to edit an article.
4. User has the ability to delete an article.

#### Follow up (You do)
Build out the "frontend" to this blogging app. Your frontend should (for now) get each **PUBLIC** board the user has, run through all the lists to get all the cards, and display those cards in reverse-chronological order. 

This project is pretty data-retrieval heavy.
